Red Flag / Indicator Rule: Client provides information that is misleading, vague, hard to verify, or refuses to identify beneficial owners.
Common identifiers (addresses, phone numbers, IP) used by multiple apparently unrelated clients.
Client occupation (e.g., student, unemployed, homemaker) is inconsistent with transaction volume or wealth.
Client presents Chinese passport/visa with identical photos allegedly issued years apart.
Client displays nervous behavior, avoids contact, or is defensive when questioned.
Sudden change in client's financial profile or pattern of activity.
Client opens accounts for several businesses for no apparent economic reason.
Accounts opened in the name of a foundation/association linked to suspected terrorist organizations.
High-volume cash deposits/withdrawals followed immediately by wire transfers or drafts (Pass-through activity).
Structuring cash deposits at multiple branches/ABMs to avoid reporting thresholds (Smurfing).
Cash activity occurs between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m.
Frequent use of white-label ATMs (e.g., in hotels, convenience stores, casinos).
Trucking/Logistics employees making excessive cash deposits, particularly along known drug corridors.
Large volumes of cash delivered via Armored Car Services (ACS) for a business with no apparent lawful purpose.
Large volume of cash delivered to US financial institution via ACS on behalf of a Mexico-based business.
Shipment of bulk cash delivered via ACS without accompanying instructions.
Wire transfers to/from high-risk jurisdictions (e.g., China, Mexico, Colombia) without apparent business purpose.
Wires sent to chemical companies or brokers in China (Hebei/Hubei provinces), Eastern Europe, or India.
Large transfers between senders and receivers with no apparent relationship.
Wires routed through intermediary jurisdictions (Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore) to conceal final destination.
Client receives wires marked 'tuition' or 'living expenses' but funds are used for unrelated purposes (e.g., real estate, luxury goods).
Mexico-based business transporting cash into US provides inconsistent info on currency originator in CMIR.
High volume of incoming EMTs rapidly depleted by outgoing EMTs to unrelated third parties.
EMTs containing references to drug slang (e.g., 'fent', 'china girl', 'dragon’s breath').
EMTs referencing 'escort', 'massage', or names of escort agencies.
Multiple EMTs from unrelated third parties sent to the same beneficiary.
Excessive credit card payments or overpayments followed by cash advances.
Use of prepaid cards to do card-to-card transfers (e.g., male funding a female's card).
Use of bank drafts/cheques to purchase real estate or vehicles inconsistent with client profile.
Purchases at merchants selling gift cards/prepaid cards in rounded sums.
Transactions along known drug corridors (e.g., Vancouver -> Calgary -> Saskatchewan; Toronto -> London/Hamilton).
Funds transferred to/from jurisdictions with weak AML controls or known for drug production.
Hotel/accommodation bookings in multiple cities over a short period.
Incoming funds from China/HK used for structured draft purchases to developers referencing specific units/addresses.
Use of 'straw buyers' or nominees to purchase property.
US escrow company receives funds from unaffiliated foreign shell company to purchase real estate.
Funds from China/HK used to buy cars at high-end dealerships inconsistent with student/homemaker profile.
Circular flow of funds between used car dealerships and import/export entities.
Business accounts receiving wires for export of goods but never purchasing inventory (TBML).
Electronics/Luxury goods businesses receiving wires from unrelated jurisdictions (e.g., Mexico, UAE) with no business nexus.
Hong Kong registered trading companies with shell-like characteristics sending funds with no economic purpose.
Funds sent to legal professionals (trust accounts) with no clear relationship or stated purpose.
Use of virtual currency (VC) to purchase precursor chemicals or pay chemical brokers.
Transfers to VC exchanges sourced from multiple incoming EMTs.
Interaction with VC addresses linked to darknet markets or mixing services.
Payments for escort ads, website hosting, or online marketing for sexual services.
Purchases at online gambling sites using funds from multiple third-party EMTs.
Payments for luxury goods (jewelry, designer clothing) inconsistent with income.
Payments for industrial lab equipment (pill presses, pumps) without business need.
Purchases of mailing/shipping materials not commensurate with business activity (micro-trafficking).
Client appears to be acting on behalf of another party (Nominee/Gatekeeper).
Use of 'daigou' (shopping on behalf of others) to move funds or purchase luxury goods.
